item.title: Dashboard to monitor COVID-19 situation in Sri Lanka.
item.description:
Visit here: https://statisticsmart.shinyapps.io/coronaSLDashboard/#section-summary

Code

The code behind this dashboard is available on GitHub.

Data

The raw data is pulled from the Johns Hopkins University Center for Systems Science and Engineering (JHU CCSE) Coronavirus repository (through corona package in R) and Covid-19 Situation reports published by Epidemiology Unit, Ministry of Health and Indigenous Medical Services, Sri Lanka.

Update

The map data is as of Sunday March 22, 2020 and the dashboard has been updated on Friday March 27, 2020.

To explore Global trend use Rami Krispinâ€™s dashboard

Visit: https://ramikrispin.github.io/coronavirus_dashboard/

item.title: How to install and load multiple packages at once?
item.description:
install packages

To install multiple packages with a single call to install.packages, pass the names of the packages as a character vector to the install.packages() function.

install.packages(c("gganimate", "tidyverse", "gapminder"))

load packages

Once you have the packages installed, you can make their contents available to use in your current R session by running,

lapply(c("gganimate", "tidyverse", "gapminder"), require, character.only = TRUE)
## [[1]]
## [1] TRUE
## 
## [[2]]
## [1] TRUE
## 
## [[3]]
## [1] TRUE

check and install missing packages

list.of.packages <- c("gganimate", "tidyverse", "gapminder")
new.packages <- list.of.packages[!(list.of.packages %in% installed.packages()[,"Package"])]
if(length(new.packages)) install.packages(new.packages)

For other alternatives see

  1. littler
library(littler)
install.r EIAdata gdata ggmap ggplot2
  1. ipak
ipak <- function(pkg){
    new.pkg <- pkg[!(pkg %in% installed.packages()[, "Package"])]
    if (length(new.pkg)) 
        install.packages(new.pkg, dependencies = TRUE)
    sapply(pkg, require, character.only = TRUE)
}

# usage
packages <- c("gganimate", "tidyverse", "gapminder")
ipak(packages)
## gganimate tidyverse gapminder 
##      TRUE      TRUE      TRUE
  1. easypackages

item.title: Some useful Greek letters you might use on your reports
item.description:
alpha: beta: gamma delta
\alpha : \(\alpha\) \beta: \(\beta\) \gamma: \(\gamma\) \delta: \(\delta\)
\Gamma: \(\Gamma\) \Delta: \(\Delta\)
epsilon Zeta eta theta
\epsilon: \(\epsilon\) \zeta: \(\zeta\) \eta: \(\eta\) \theta: \(\theta\)
\varepsilon: \(\varepsilon\) \Theta: \(\Theta\)
iota kappa lambda mu
\iota: \(\iota\) \kappa: \(\kappa\) \lambda: \(\lambda\) \mu: \(\mu\)
nu xi pi rho
\nu: \(\nu\) \xi: \(\xi\) \pi: \(\pi\) \rho: \(\rho\)
\Xi: \(\Xi\) \Pi: \(\Pi\)
sigma upsilon phi omicron
\sigma: \(\sigma\) \upsilon: \(\upsilon\) \phi: \(\phi\) \omicron: \(\omicron\)
\Sigma: \(\Sigma\) \Phi: \(\Phi\)
tau chi psi Omega
\tau: \(\tau\) \chi: \(\chi\) \psi: \(\psi\) \omega: \(\omega\)
\Psi: \(\Psi\) \Omega: \(\Omega\)

item.title: What's in a package?
item.description:
Sometimes we need to view all the functions that are built into an R package. This is done in the same way you would list variables in your workspace, using the ls function. Note that the package must be loaded before you run the ls command.

Usage: Getting a list of functions inside the dplyr package

library(dplyr)
ls("package:dplyr")
##   [1] "%>%"                   "add_count"            
##   [3] "add_count_"            "add_row"              
##   [5] "add_rownames"          "add_tally"            
##   [7] "add_tally_"            "all_equal"            
##   [9] "all_vars"              "anti_join"            
##  [11] "any_vars"              "arrange"              
##  [13] "arrange_"              "arrange_all"          
##  [15] "arrange_at"            "arrange_if"           
##  [17] "as_data_frame"         "as_label"             
##  [19] "as_tibble"             "as.tbl"               
##  [21] "as.tbl_cube"           "auto_copy"            
##  [23] "band_instruments"      "band_instruments2"    
##  [25] "band_members"          "bench_tbls"           
##  [27] "between"               "bind_cols"            
##  [29] "bind_rows"             "case_when"            
##  [31] "changes"               "check_dbplyr"         
##  [33] "coalesce"              "collapse"             
##  [35] "collect"               "combine"              
##  [37] "common_by"             "compare_tbls"         
##  [39] "compare_tbls2"         "compute"              
##  [41] "contains"              "copy_to"              
##  [43] "count"                 "count_"

##  [47] "cume_dist"             "cummean"
